title: Marriage Story: Scarlett Johansson film will hit you in the feels
text:

It would be no surprise to Noah Baumbach fans that his latest film, Marriage Story, is focused on the small moments.

The director, famed for indie dramas such as Squid and the Whale and Frances Ha, has created a style around his stories focusing on well-to-do New Yorkers talking over each other as they deal with life, love, and, centrally, family.

While the strong similarities between his films cause a few to feel like they’re treading water rather than breaking new ground, the extremely-apparent personal nature of his works is always a draw.

Scarlett and Adam lead Marriage Story (Picture: Netflix)

Marriage Story is, as many people are already calling it, much more of a divorce story.

Nicole (Scarlett Johansson) and Charlie (Adam Driver) are a couple with a young son in New York, they both work in a theatre company where he’s the director and she’s the star actress, and they’re going to separate.

The details of this break up aren’t what’s important, with key moments of their prior relationship and their lives throughout the divorce only being briefly mentioned in conversations. We’re instead shown moments of comedy and intimacy that feel completely regular yet also entirely important to the narrative, all of which are delightful and captivating.

This is of course mostly due to the stunning performances from Driver and Johansson.

The pair navigate separation (Picture: Netflix)

Each digs into their characters’ personalities and ticks in ways that balance and oppose each other brilliantly. It brings the script, that could have easily tipped from siding with one side or the other, to a place where you end up feeling awful for everyone involved.

Although the latter half the film does seem to shift away from focusing on Johansson to the stories detriment.

What may seem scattershot moments at first, flitting from quick montages to lengthy conversations, become rewarding as the film goes on.

Throwaway jokes and lines become ammunition when returned in new contexts, as the couple continues to fracture apart. It feels much more structured and intricate than Baumbach’s previous films without losing any of the spontaneous feeling.

The film is out next month (Picture: Netflix)

Ultimately it becomes a film about how easy it is to hurt someone else, and how equally easy it is to not even realise the pain you’ve caused. About how the small moments stack upon one another until it’s too much to take apart piece by piece. And about how we’ve built up these systems and societal norms that push us to keep hurting each other to get what we want above all else.

While many may take the film as sad, watching its central couple spiral further away from each other with increasing anger and pettiness, its story wraps with a moment that brings it all back around to a place of love; where these small moments can heal just as much as they hurt.

Marriage Story is in cinemas 6 November and on Netflix 6 December.
description: Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver's Marriage Story will hit you right in the feels.
